author: Jessica Brown
title: Barack Obama flies to island in French Polynesia to relax at luxury resort 'The Brando'
text:
News Barack Obama flies to island in French Polynesia to relax at luxury resort 'The Brando' Former President of the United States Barack Obama learning to kitesurf on the British Virgin Islands after he finished his second term as President, February 2017 Credit: PA Jessica Brown 16 March 2017 • 12:00pm 
W here do you go if you recently handed over the reins to one of the most stressful jobs in the world, have memoirs worth $60 million (£49 million) to write, and have a new-found love of kitesurfing? 
For Barack Obama, the answer is French Polynesia. The former US president slipped quietly into Tahiti by private jet yesterday, touching down at Faa’a International Airport near the capital of Papeete at about 3.30pm. He is expected to stay in French Polynesia for the next month, but his initial visit to Tahiti was a short one. Former President of the United States Barack Obama learning to kitesurf on the British Virgin Islands after he finished his second term as President, February 2017 Credit: PA 
A ccording to local television channel Tahiti Nui TV, Mr Obama left the island just 30 minutes later aboard a smaller, private plane bound for eco-luxe resort The Brando on the nearby atoll of Tetiaroa. Formerly the Tahitian royal family's favourite retreat, Tetiaroa later became the home of legendary actor Marlon Brando, who bought parts of the idyllic atoll in the 1960s. 
More recently, it has charmed Hollywood royalty such as Leonardo DiCaprio, who celebrated his birthday at The Brando in November 2016. Voted "Best Resort in the World" by Condé Nast Traveler readers last year, The Brando is powered by solar energy and coconut oil, cooled by a sea water air conditioning system, and home to an innovative mosquito eradication project involving researchers from Oxford University. Barack Obama's plane arriving in Tahiti Credit: Tahiti Nui Télévision 
A ctivities available to Mr Obama during his stay at the sumptuous resort, which costs up to €12,300 (£10,745) a night, will include snorkelling, tennis, and visits to the atoll’s turtle sanctuary. 
T etiaroa is also a renowned kitesurfing spot, meaning Mr Obama can practise the skills he picked up with Sir Richard Branson during his recent holiday on the entrepreneur’s private Necker Island. Sir Richard Branson and former President of the United States Barack Obama on the British Virgin Islands, February 2017 Credit: PA 
M r Obama is thought to be taking time out in the South Pacific to write his memoirs, for which he and Michelle are reported to have signed a deal worth $60 million with publisher Penguin Random House. He is expected to visit some of the other islands in French Polynesia, including honeymoon hotspot Bora Bora, during his stay. 
Locally, there is also speculation that he will spend time on his friend, billionaire film producer David Geffen’s $300-million yacht, which was moored in Papeete earlier this week and is now off the coast of neighbouring island Moorea. 
Dreamworks founder Mr Geffen has been a big supporter of Mr Obama over the years, throwing the first big Hollywood fundraiser in support of his 2008 run for presidency. It is not known whether Michelle Obama will join her husband during his stay.
